I know how triggering that would be for a city that was locked down for 111 days last year. To know that 40% of aged care facilities in Melbourne have not been fully vaccinated and I think, scandalously, 29 have not received even a single dose when they were promised all across the country to be vaccinated fully by Easter. Given what we know happened last year, I think must be very distressing for everyone. For those trying to work out the number of Covid cases linked to this latest outbreak in Victoria, it‚Äôs at 26. One of the 12 cases was mentioned by James Merlino at yesterday‚Äôs press conference. So that makes 11 new cases (the ones we didn‚Äôt know about) but 12 in total. Day four of estimates is getting under way ‚Äì a little bit later in the day we will hear from officials within the finance department who deal with Parliament House staffing issues, so we‚Äôll bring you updates from that. The latest Victoria Health numbers are out: Richard Colbeck was pressed on the 29 Victorian aged care homes who were yet to receive any vaccines (aged care is a federal responsibility) outside the Nine studios: I‚Äôm very comfortable with the rollout of the vaccination across the ‚Äì across the country. About 85% of residents across Australia have taken up the vaccine. And it‚Äôs been a significant logistical effort. There‚Äôs some providers who have put back their vaccine dates so that the residents can get flu vaccinations. We have worked with the providers to schedule them over the last 12 or 13 weeks to get the vaccines. Here is a rundown of the various reports of a lockdown flagged for Victoria. No detail has been given about whether the lockdown will affect the whole state or just greater Melbourne. The Age reports: ‚ÄúA source close to the government, who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss the confidential decision, said cabinet was set to confirm final details of the lockdown on Thursday morning before announcing the public health measures.‚Äù According to the Age, this lockdown will last at least three days, with the finer details being discussed this morning. The ABC is reporting that the cluster has grown overnight to 25 cases, with reporter Richard Willingham saying the lockdown will last at least five days. This is the problem with government leaks before the official announcement ‚Äì there is confusion about how long the lockdown will last, and which areas it will affect, creating extra anxiety. There has been no announcement of a press conference yet, we‚Äôll keep you posted when we know the details. We can expect the Victorian state government to continue to push for purpose-built quarantine facilities, given the situation that‚Äôs unfolding. Yesterday the deputy premier, James Merlino, urged that more secure quarantine facilities be designed and built, with the outbreak in Victoria originating from a hotel quarantine breach in South Australia: There is a sense of urgency about this. The best time to have had an alternative quarantine facility is 12 months ago and the next best time is now, so we are very keen to finalise those discussions with the commonwealth. There are 29 aged care facilities in Victoria which are yet to receive a single dose of vaccine from the federal government. Aged care minister Richard Colbeck was on the Nine Network this morning explaining why, as Melbourne looks about to enter another lockdown because of a Covid outbreak, sparked from a breach in Adelaide hotel quarantine: They should be done in the next few days. We‚Äôve prioritised those. We‚Äôve been working our way obviously across the country. There‚Äôs about 600 facilities that the commonwealth has responsibility for in Victoria. As you said, 29 of those left to be done. They were programmed to be done. They were programmed to be done this week or next week, so we‚Äôll get those finalised as quickly as we can. We‚Äôre actually going back over other facilities, particularly in those areas of Melbourne where there has been an outbreak. The average vaccination rate across aged care in Australia is about 85%. There‚Äôs some that are lower than that so we‚Äôre going back and offering people a second chance to take up a vaccine if that‚Äôs what they‚Äôd like, given the current circumstances. Scott Morrison has also taken to reminding people how bad Covid could have been in Australia if it weren‚Äôt for the measures put in place (largely pushed by the states). Yesterday he accused the opposition of ‚Äúwhinging‚Äù about the vaccine rollout and said people stopped him on the street to say how happy they were: I know that Australians ‚Äì because they approach me every time when I go out into regional Australia or the suburbs and cities of this country ‚Äì they know here, in this country, they‚Äôre living a life during Covid like few are anywhere else in the world. This country has enjoyed safety from this pandemic and an economic recovery like few, if any, other countries in the world. Those opposite, Mr Speaker, may want to retreat into whinging and complaining and undermining the government, as we fight the virus and they focus on the politics. (Nice order of importance there too, in terms of the geographical indicators he used in that sentence.) Kristina Keneally spoke to ABC News Breakfast about that attitude this morning: Well, if we take that argument from the prime minister at face value ‚Äì well, 17 outbreaks in six months ‚Äì ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve never had it so good, what are you complaining about?‚Äù Let me tell you, the people of Melbourne today who are facing the prospect of another extended lockdown, they would disagree with the prime minister. They would say, ‚ÄúYou got a report, prime minister, some nine months ago from Jane Halton, your handpicked expert, who told you hotel quarantine is not fit-for-purpose.‚Äù Hotels are for tourists, not for quarantine and medical purposes. We rolled it out at the beginning of the pandemic because we needed something quickly. But we now know so much more about this virus, we know it is airborne, we know hotels are not fit-for-purpose for quarantine. Jane Halton gave the prime minister multiple recommendations and he has failed to act on a single one of them. He could be, for example, taking up Victoria‚Äôs offer of the Mickleham facility and expanding that. He could be working with Queensland, with their offer to expand and work with him on a national quarantine system in that state. He could be looking at Bladin Point in the Northern Territory. Yet this is a prime minister who thinks that this is not his problem. He wants to shove everything onto the states ‚Äì everything is someone else‚Äôs responsibility, and nothing is his fault. In a national pandemic, and an international pandemic, that is simply not good enough from our prime minister. Looking to some other news at the moment, a significant judgment has just come out of The Hague: A court in The Hague has ordered Royal Dutch Shell to cut its global carbon emissions by 45% by the end of 2030 compared with 2019 levels, in a landmark case brought by Friends of the Earth and over 17,000 co-plaintiffs. The oil giant‚Äôs sustainability policy was found to be insufficiently ‚Äúconcrete‚Äù by the Dutch court in an unprecedented ruling that will have wide implications for the energy industry and other polluting multinationals. The Anglo-Dutch company was told it had a duty of care and that the level of emission reductions of Shell and its suppliers and buyers should be brought into line with the Paris climate agreement. More than a year on from the start of the pandemic, after hotel quarantine breaches in all states and with no end in sight, you have to wonder why more people aren‚Äôt screaming for purpose-built quarantine facilities. Scott Morrison has taken to saying that hotel quarantine is 99.9% effective. But, as we are seeing from one of those 0.01% of failures, which is happening to Melbourne after a breach in an Adelaide quarantine hotel, the cost on communities is very, very high. Hotel quarantine was set up in a couple of weeks in an answer to new problems. Hotels are not set up as quarantine spaces. They have shared ventilation, for starters. We have learnt more about the virus and more about the impact of airborne particles. This is not something the federal government can continue to shrug off. Meanwhile, back in 1950, John ‚Äúlots of numbers‚Äù Troll has something to say about parents in the workplace: We are expecting the Victorian press conference to be held about 9.30am or so. I‚Äôm so sorry, Melbourne. We will hopefully be hearing from Victorian authorities soon. The Herald Sun has reported the possibility of a five-day lockdown is on the cards, given the number of exposure sites. That also includes Marvel Stadium ‚Äì anyone sitting on level one, between rows five and 28 and level three between aisles six and 29 is considered a tier 2 contact ‚Äì and must get a Covid test and isolate until results come in. (That was Sunday‚Äôs Essendon v North Melbourne game.) You may have heard a lot from Peter Dutton lately about defence spending. Daniel Hurst has taken a look at a small slither of that spend: Australia‚Äôs defence department has revealed it is spending $37m to hire private helicopters as it grapples with low availability of the trouble-plagued Taipan choppers. The move comes as defence officials concede a fault found in one of the helicopters in 2019 ‚Äì when it was on its way to pick up the Australian defence force chief, Angus Campbell ‚Äì could have led to ‚Äúcatastrophic consequences‚Äù if left unfixed. It has prompted the opposition to blast the Howard government-era acquisition of the Multi-Role Helicopters (MRH90), also known as Taipans, as ‚Äúa farce from go to whoa‚Äù. Australia needs to avoid adding to a global ‚Äúrace to the bottom‚Äù over military ambitions in space, amid concerns that the major powers are seeking to dominate space, according to a new report. The Australian defence force is setting up a space division at the Royal Australian Air Force headquarters in Canberra early next year, with the government planning to spend $7bn on space capabilities over the next decade. The government has also launched an Australian Space Agency. Dr Cassandra Steer, a senior lecturer at the Australian National University‚Äôs college of law who specialises in space law, said space was ‚Äúa critical strategic domain for Australia‚Äôs civilian and military interests‚Äù but was ‚Äúincreasingly congested, contested and competitive‚Äù. She said major powers were engaged in ‚Äúa destabilising space arms race‚Äù, with China, Russia and the US rejecting the strategic restraint that had kept space a stable political and military domain. In a policy options paper published by the ANU‚Äôs national security college today, Steer said Australia could act as a ‚Äúmiddle space power‚Äù and encourage responsible behaviour in space. She argued Australian leaders should ‚Äúavoid inadvertently contributing to escalatory rhetoric‚Äù. That meant avoiding descriptions of space as a ‚Äúwarfighting domain‚Äù or a ‚Äúbattlespace‚Äù: Australia needs to be careful that, as it develops sovereign space capabilities, it does not accelerate a global strategic race to the bottom. Rather, Australia should focus on its ability to become an effective diplomatic space power ‚Äì building on our history as a strong contributor to space technologies and arms control norms. The paper calls on the government to invest in space literacy training across the Australian public service and for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to appoint a ‚Äúspace ambassador‚Äù with a dedicated team to influence the space agenda internationally. While you were sleeping, US president Joe Biden ordered an intelligence investigation into the origins of the coronavirus. You can read the Guardian‚Äôs full story here: We start this morning with the news that the list of exposure sites in Victoria has grown to 70. I think we can expect further social distancing measures to be announced today in response to that ‚Äì it‚Äôs a huge list. It includes a NSW western Riverina sporting club in Tooleybuc, which is near the Victorian border. A positive case attended a football match at Cohuna which the Tooleybuc club was at. Anyone who was at the Cohuna recreation reserve on Saturday 22 May between 12pm and 5pm must get a Covid test and isolate until they receive their results. NSW has already officially asked all residents to rethink any non-urgent travel to greater Melbourne or Bendigo. South Australia has gone further and shut its borders to Melbourne residents as of 6pm last night. We‚Äôll keep across everything that happens as it does, as well as parliament and estimates. I know this is Politics Live, but we want you to have all the information you need as quickly as possible. As always, I‚Äôll highlight important events ‚Äì and we‚Äôll pull out all the important information in stories where you can quickly find it. You have Katharine Murphy, Mike Bowers, Sarah Martin and Paul Karp in Canberra. Our Melbourne team is also on deck keeping you abreast of all that is happening there. And you have Amy Remeikis on the blog for most of the day. Melbourne, we‚Äôre thinking of you. Ready?

headline: Christian Porter and ABC to enter mediation on defamation claim
standfirst: The former attorney general agrees to mediation ahead of a federal court ruling on whether one of his barristers can represent him in the case
trailText: The former attorney general agrees to mediation ahead of a federal court ruling on whether one of his barristers can represent him in the case
body:
Christian Porter and the ABC are entering into mediation in the former attorney general‚Äôs high-stakes defamation claim against the national broadcaster.

A federal court order made on Thursday revealed the two parties had agreed to provide unredacted copies of the ABC‚Äôs defence and Porter‚Äôs reply to a mediator in connection with the proceedings, potentially foreshadowing an attempt to settle the case before it reaches a trial.

It comes as the fate of Porter‚Äôs barrister hangs in the balance after an urgent four-day hearing to decide whether she should be blocked from acting for the former attorney general in his defamation case came to a close.

Related: Friends of Christian Porter‚Äôs accuser threatened to make things ‚Äòvery bad‚Äô for his barrister, court hears

Federal court justice Thomas Thawley indicated that he would deliver his judgement on whether Sydney defamation specialist Sue Chrysanthou SC should be prevented from acting for Porter in the case against the ABC on Thursday afternoon.

The case was bought by Dyer, who claims Chrysanthou has a conflict of interest because of a meeting the women had in 2020 regarding an article in the Australian newspaper by Janet Albrechtsen about a November ABC Four Corners episode Dyer appeared in.

In his closing submissions on Thursday, Dyer‚Äôs barrister, Michael Hodge QC, told the court there were four main issues in the case: the ‚Äúfactual contest‚Äù of what was said at the 20 November meeting, the potential ‚Äúmisuse of confidential information‚Äù said to have been relayed there, whether that information has ‚Äúsince all become public‚Äù and the public‚Äôs perception of the administration of justice.

The 20 November meeting had taken place after a friend of Chrysanthou‚Äôs, fellow barrister Matthew Richardson, asked her to attend the meeting to give advice about a concerns notice Dyer wanted to send to the Australian over the Albrechtsen article.

Chrysanthou had originally said she first learned about the concerns notice during a brief ‚Äúwalk-and-talk‚Äù meeting with Richardson, but subsequently conceded she had ‚Äúcombined‚Äù two separate conversations in her head after emails produced showed Richardson had previously emailed her about the meeting.

That, Hodge said, showed Chrysanthou‚Äôs ‚Äúfrailties of memory‚Äù could not be relied upon for what was said to have occurred at the meeting.

While Chrysanthou had argued she could not recall any confidential information from the meeting, Hodge argued during the case that a last-minute confidential affidavit lodged by James Hooke, a friend of both Porter‚Äôs and his accuser, who was also at the 20 November meeting, had ‚Äúswe[pt] away the last vestiges‚Äù of that claim.

During her cross-examination Chrysanthou told the court she could not recall Hooke saying anything of substance during the meeting, but, while the alleged confidential information remained secret, Hodge told the court in his closing it was ‚Äúinherently improbable‚Äù that those things were not discussed.

‚ÄúYour honour should not accept Ms Chrysanthou‚Äôs evidence insofar as it‚Äôs said that evidence conflicts with Mr Hooke, Ms Dyer and [her solicitor Michael] Bradley as to what was said in the conference,‚Äù he said.

But arguing on behalf of Chrysanthou, Porter‚Äôs barrister, Christopher Withers SC, said that all of the information disclosed during the 20 November meeting had either since become public, or was known by the ABC. He spent much of his closing taking justice Thawley through a schedule of documents he said showed the information was not confidential, or was not beneficial or relevant to Porter‚Äôs claim.

Withers also argued the events described by Hooke in his affidavit seem ‚Äúinherently implausible‚Äù, in part because of an email sent to Chrysanthou from Dyer‚Äôs solicitor, Michael Bradley, after the meeting in which he described it as ‚Äúhighly entertaining‚Äù.

‚ÄúThat seems inconsistent with the notion they were discussing some of the topics Hooke says were discussed, which are inherently distressing topics,‚Äù he said.

Justice Thawley interrupted at that point to say he wasn‚Äôt sure: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen some of Mr Bradley‚Äôs Tweets, he has a certain way with words‚Äù.

Withers also argued that Dyer was not a party to the case, and questioned assertion‚Äôs made in Dyer‚Äôs affidavit that she would be a witness in Porter‚Äôs defamation trial.

‚ÄúMs Dyer‚Äôs concise statement positively pleads that she will be a witness [but] gradually the submissions have been watered down,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúClosely analysing the pleading, it‚Äôs just not at all apparent how she would play a role in the case because it‚Äôs the question of the ABC‚Äôs state of mind at issue,‚Äù he said.

The trial was subject to a number of twists, with Porter‚Äôs lawyers failing in a bid to block Hooke‚Äôs last minute affidavit, saying it had the potential to ‚Äúderail‚Äù the timing of his defamation case.

The court also heard during Dyer‚Äôs cross-examination that she wanted the allegations against Porter to be made public in a bid to stop him ever becoming prime minister, and that the ABC journalist who published the story at the centre of the defamation case, Louise Milligan, had warned her to delete messages.

During cross-examination on Wednesday, Chrysanthou said she had been warned by Richardson that the friends of Porter‚Äôs accuser had been ‚Äúacting like a cult‚Äù and would make things ‚Äúvery bad‚Äù for her if she took on his defamation case.

headline: Australian court finds government has duty to protect young people from climate crisis
standfirst: Eight teenagers, along with 86-year-old nun, launched case to prevent the approval of a massive coalmine
trailText: Eight teenagers, along with 86-year-old nun, launched case to prevent the approval of a massive coalmine
body:
The federal court of Australia has found the environment minister, Sussan Ley, has a duty of care to protect young people from the climate crisis in a judgment hailed by lawyers and teenagers who brought the case as a world first.

Eight teenagers and an octogenarian nun had sought an injunction to prevent Ley approving a proposal by Whitehaven Coal to expand the Vickery coalmine in northern New South Wales, arguing the minister had a common law duty of care to protect younger people against future harm from climate change.

Justice Mordecai Bromberg found the minister had a duty of care to not act in a way that would cause future harm to younger people. But he did not grant the injunction as he was not satisfied the minister would breach her duty of care.

David Barnden, a lawyer representing the children, said it was a historic and ‚Äúamazing decision‚Äù with potentially significant consequences.

‚ÄúThe court has found that the minister owes a duty of care to younger children, to vulnerable people, and that duty says that the minister must not act in a way that causes harm ‚Äì future harm ‚Äì from climate change to younger people,‚Äù he said outside court. ‚ÄúIt is the first time in the world that such a duty of care has been recognised, especially in a common law country.‚Äù

Related: 'A duty of care': Australian teenagers take their climate crisis plea to court

He said Bromberg had indicated he would now take submissions before making further declarations about what the minister‚Äôs duty of care may mean for whether the mine extension could go ahead.

Whitehaven Coal had a different interpretation of the judgment. In a statement to the stock exchange, it did not mention the duty of care finding, and said it welcomed the court dismissing the teenagers‚Äô attempt to block Ley from approving the mine extension.

‚ÄúOur consistent position has been that this legal claim was without merit,‚Äù it said. ‚ÄúWhitehaven looks forward to receiving the ‚Ä¶ approval for the Vickery extension project and will keep the market updated as appropriate.‚Äù

Speaking for the children, 17-year-old Ava Princi said it was ‚Äúthrilling and deeply relieving‚Äù that the justice had recognised the minister had a duty of care.

‚ÄúI am thrilled because this is a landmark decision,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy future and the future of all young people depends on Australia stepping away from fossil fuel projects and joining the world in taking decisive climate action.‚Äù

She said though an injunction was not granted the case was ‚Äúnot over yet‚Äù. ‚ÄúThere will be further submissions on what the duty of care means for the minister‚Äôs decision and the mine,‚Äù she said.

A spokesman for Ley said the government was considering the judgment and would have ‚Äúmore to say in due course‚Äù, but noted it rejected the application for an injunction against the minister to prevent her making a final decision on the mine extension.

The teenagers, led by the 16-year-old Melbourne student Anj Sharma and supported by Sister Brigid Arthur, an 86-year-old nun and former teacher who volunteered to be their litigation guardian, argued Ley would be breaching a common law duty of care if she used her powers under national environment laws to allow Whitehaven Coal to extend the Vickery mine.

The court heard the expansion of the mine could lead to an extra 100m tonnes of CO2 ‚Äì about 20% of Australia‚Äôs annual climate footprint ‚Äì being released into the atmosphere as the extracted coal is shipped overseas and burned to make steel and generate electricity.

In his judgment, Bromberg said the evidence presented to the court showed the potential harm the children could face due to global heating ‚Äúmay fairly be described as catastrophic, particularly should global average surface temperatures rise to and exceed 3C beyond the pre-industrial level‚Äù.

‚ÄúPerhaps the most startling of the potential harms demonstrated by the evidence before the court, is that one million of today‚Äôs Australian children are expected to suffer at least one heat-stress episode serious enough to require acute care in a hospital,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúMany thousands will suffer premature death from heat stress or bushfire smoke. Substantial economic loss and property damage will be experienced. The Great Barrier Reef and most of Australia‚Äôs eastern eucalypt forests will no longer exist due to repeated, severe bushfires.‚Äù

Bromberg found that the minister had a common law duty to take reasonable care not to cause the children personal injury when using her powers under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC) Act.

He did not grant an injunction to prevent the mine extension because he had ‚Äúnot been satisfied that a reasonable apprehension of breach of the duty of care by the minister has been established‚Äù.

Related: Court orders Royal Dutch Shell to cut carbon emissions by 45% by 2030

Ley‚Äôs office was asked for its response to the judgment.

The case is one of a number of climate-related litigation cases expected before Australian courts and tribunals in the months ahead as lawyers and activists aim to use the law to force change they say is not coming quickly enough from Canberra or state governments.

There have been a growing number of international cases that aim to hold governments to account for not doing more to address global heating.

In the latest on Wednesday, a court in the Hague ordered Royal Dutch Shell to cut its global carbon emissions by 45% by the end of 2030 compared with 2019 levels after finding the oil giant‚Äôs sustainability policy was insufficiently ‚Äúconcrete‚Äù.

The Anglo-Dutch company was told it had a duty of care and that the level of emission reductions of Shell and its suppliers and buyers should be brought into line with the Paris climate agreement. The case had been brought by Friends of the Earth and over 17,000 co-plaintiffs.

The International Energy Agency last week suggested there should be no new coal, oil or gas investments if the world was to keep open the possibility of meet the goals of the Paris agreement and reaching net zero global greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

In a statement to the stock exchange, it did not mention the duty of care finding, and said it welcomed the court dismissing the teenagers‚Äô attempt to block Ley from approving the mine extension. ‚ÄúOur consistent position has been that this legal claim was without merit,‚Äù it said. ‚ÄúWhitehaven looks forward to receiving the ‚Ä¶ approval for the Vickery extension project and will keep the market updated as appropriate.‚Äù Speaking for the children, 17-year-old Ava Princi said it was ‚Äúthrilling and deeply relieving‚Äù that the justice had recognised the minister had a duty of care. ‚ÄúI am thrilled because this is a landmark decision,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy future and the future of all young people depends on Australia stepping away from fossil fuel projects and joining the world in taking decisive climate action.‚Äù She said though an injunction was not granted the case was ‚Äúnot over yet‚Äù. ‚ÄúThere will be further submissions on what the duty of care means for the minister‚Äôs decision and the mine,‚Äù she said. A spokesman for Ley said the government was considering the judgment and would have ‚Äúmore to say in due course‚Äù, but noted it rejected the application for an injunction against the minister to prevent her making a final decision on the mine extension. The teenagers, led by the 16-year-old Melbourne student Anj Sharma and supported by Sister Brigid Arthur, an 86-year-old nun and former teacher who volunteered to be their litigation guardian, argued Ley would be breaching a common law duty of care if she used her powers under national environment laws to allow Whitehaven Coal to extend the Vickery mine. The court heard the expansion of the mine could lead to an extra 100m tonnes of CO2 ‚Äì about 20% of Australia‚Äôs annual climate footprint ‚Äì being released into the atmosphere as the extracted coal is shipped overseas and burned to make steel and generate electricity. In his judgment, Bromberg said the evidence presented to the court showed the potential harm the children could face due to global heating ‚Äúmay fairly be described as catastrophic, particularly should global average surface temperatures rise to and exceed 3C beyond the pre-industrial level‚Äù. ‚ÄúPerhaps the most startling of the potential harms demonstrated by the evidence before the court, is that one million of today‚Äôs Australian children are expected to suffer at least one heat-stress episode serious enough to require acute care in a hospital,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMany thousands will suffer premature death from heat stress or bushfire smoke. Substantial economic loss and property damage will be experienced. The Great Barrier Reef and most of Australia‚Äôs eastern eucalypt forests will no longer exist due to repeated, severe bushfires.‚Äù Bromberg found that the minister had a common law duty to take reasonable care not to cause the children personal injury when using her powers under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC) Act. He did not grant an injunction to prevent the mine extension because he had ‚Äúnot been satisfied that a reasonable apprehension of breach of the duty of care by the minister has been established‚Äù. Ley‚Äôs office was asked for its response to the judgment. The case is one of a number of climate-related litigation cases expected before Australian courts and tribunals in the months ahead as lawyers and activists aim to use the law to force change they say is not coming quickly enough from Canberra or state governments. There have been a growing number of international cases that aim to hold governments to account for not doing more to address global heating. In the latest on Wednesday, a court in the Hague ordered Royal Dutch Shell to cut its global carbon emissions by 45% by the end of 2030 compared with 2019 levels after finding the oil giant‚Äôs sustainability policy was insufficiently ‚Äúconcrete‚Äù. The Anglo-Dutch company was told it had a duty of care and that the level of emission reductions of Shell and its suppliers and buyers should be brought into line with the Paris climate agreement. The case had been brought by Friends of the Earth and over 17,000 co-plaintiffs. The International Energy Agency last week suggested there should be no new coal, oil or gas investments if the world was to keep open the possibility of meet the goals of the Paris agreement and reaching net zero global greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

headline: Australia‚Äôs ambassador to China denied entry to trial of Yang Hengjun
standfirst: Envoy raps Beijing for failing ‚Äòtreaty obligation‚Äô to allow consular access to author accused of spying
trailText: Envoy raps Beijing for failing ‚Äòtreaty obligation‚Äô to allow consular access to author accused of spying
body:
Australia‚Äôs ambassador to China has labelled the treatment of Yang Hengjun ‚Äúarbitrary detention‚Äù on the morning of the writer‚Äôs closed-door trial for espionage charges.

The envoy, Graham Fletcher, was on Thursday denied entry to the Beijing court where Yang will be tried after spending more than two years in jail.

‚ÄúThe reason given was because of the pandemic situation but the foreign minister has also told us it‚Äôs because it‚Äôs a national security case,‚Äù Fletcher said outside court.

‚ÄúThis is deeply regrettable and concerning and unsatisfactory. We‚Äôve had longstanding concerns about this case, including the lack of transparency, and therefore have concluded it is an instance of arbitrary detention.‚Äù

Related: Yang Hengjun: Australian writer says he is unafraid of ‚Äòsuffering and torture‚Äô ahead of trial in China

Yang ‚Äì an Australian academic, author of spy novels, democracy activist and former employee of China‚Äôs state security ministry ‚Äì has been detained since January 2019. He was arrested immediately on arrival at Guangzhou airport while travelling with his wife and son. He was formally charged with conducting espionage on behalf of a foreign country but Chinese authorities have not identified the country. Australia‚Äôs prime minister, Scott Morrison, has said it is ‚Äúabsolutely untrue‚Äù to say Yang had acted as a spy for Australia.

The detainee was initially held in ‚Äúresidential surveillance at a designated location‚Äù ‚Äì a secretive form of detention denying access to lawyers and family, which has been classified by UN human rights experts as a type of enforced disappearance ‚Äì before being moved to a Beijing detention facility. Over the past two years Yang reported being interrogated more than 300 times by dozens of different people, for hours at a time. He has maintained his innocence of all charges.

In a letter released on Wednesday, Yang accused the Chinese government of taking revenge on him for his writing, but said he was unafraid of the ‚Äúsuffering and torture‚Äù of a long prison sentence.

‚ÄúThere is nothing more liberating than having one‚Äôs worst fears realised,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI have no fear now. I will never compromise.‚Äù

China‚Äôs notoriously opaque justice system is even more so when it comes to national security cases involving foreigners. Fletcher said the only information the Australian government had received about the case was that Yang‚Äôs charges related to espionage. He was critical of the refusal to allow him or others access to the courtroom.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a treaty obligation [to allow consular access] and it‚Äôs also necessary to give, not only our government but other governments, confidence in the process.‚Äù

A verdict could be delivered on Thursday. The court system routinely reports conviction rates of about 99%, and Yang‚Äôs charges carry lengthy terms.

‚ÄúRegardless of what happens today we will continue to advocate strongly for Dr Yang and his interests and rights, and continue to offer consular support to him and his family,‚Äù Fletcher said.

Australia‚Äôs foreign affairs minister, Marise Payne, said Yang had ‚Äúdelayed and limited‚Äù access to a lawyer, who had last visited him on 21 May.

‚ÄúI very much hope that we have a transparent and open process,‚Äù Payne told ABC radio on Thursday. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not interfering in China‚Äôs legal system. The concerns that we have raised are legitimate ones. But we do expect those basic international standards of justice to be met.‚Äù

Related: Joe Biden orders US intelligence to intensify efforts to study Covid‚Äôs origins

Last week Payne criticised China‚Äôs refusal to give Australia information about the case in a statement the Chinese foreign ministry labelled ‚Äúdeplorable‚Äù.

Yang‚Äôs trial was due to start in January but was delayed for several months until an announcement last week that it was scheduled for Thursday.

His case is one of several prosecutions of foreigners from countries now in dispute with Beijing. Another Australian, the journalist Cheng Lei, has been detained for more than eight months on similarly vague national security charges. On Thursday Fletcher said there was no reason to link Yang‚Äôs case to the relationship between China and Australia.

Human Rights Watch‚Äôs Australia researcher, Sophie McNeill, said Yang had been denied the right to a fair trial ‚Äúfrom the moment he was detained over two years ago‚Äù.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been ill-treated, shackled, denied contact with his family, blocked from accessing his lawyer ‚Äì and now Chinese authorities are indicating Australian diplomats cannot attend the trial. This case is an indictment of Beijing‚Äôs nakedly politicised legal system, but it‚Äôs Yang who‚Äôll pay the price.‚Äù

headline: Country diary: the queen bee is a ray of sunshine in a gloomy May
standfirst: Wenlock Edge, Shropshire: Spring has been hard for insects, but the garden bumblebee is here, piloted by an ancient impulse
trailText: Wenlock Edge, Shropshire: Spring has been hard for insects, but the garden bumblebee is here, piloted by an ancient impulse
body:
The queen makes a solar landing. During the briefest moment of shine in the wash cycle of our local low-pressure area, a queen garden bumblebee, Bombus hortorum, settles on a dandelion. The flower‚Äôs brilliance draws insects to its gravitational field and the promise of mining the flaring florets for nectar and pollen.

But this burning sun of a flower is cold comfort. May has been hard: blossom battered by hail, frosts, rain, rain and more rain. The gardens the bumblebee gets her name from have saturated, ‚Äúcan‚Äôt get on it‚Äù soil, struggling seedlings and soggy blooms. Birdsong is muted, wildflowers thin. The fields are sodden, the rivers close to flood. I suppose we‚Äôre lucky we haven‚Äôt had a drought and the hills aren‚Äôt on fire, but we have made insect life hard enough without a washout spring.

Apart from a defiant common blue butterfly, and gnats that catch the fleeting beams to dance between the downpours, the air is quiet. After anxious days of waiting, the swifts scream their arrival around the church tower ‚Äì but where do they go in the rain and what aerial plankton is there to trawl up there when all is drowned down here? Perhaps, at night, they fly into the moon‚Äôs halo, where they are changed and one day may not return.

There are other signs of misfortune down here, too: new fences to block old ways around fields, verges of cow parsley mowed down, magpies caught in Larsen traps, gunfire. There are harsher changes afoot in this landscape, and a resentful cynicism gaining confidence. Still, to walk from our claggy enclosures into the woods, to sigh that mean-spirited humour out and begin a forest breath full of green light under leafy ceilings fresh with rain, is to thank our lucky stars.

The queen is making up for lost time. As if piloted by some ancient entity inside a protective space suit of bumblebee anatomy, with sensory devices attuned to a world behind the rain, on wings which set the frequency for spring, she finds the fire to which we are all drawn.

‚Ä¢ Country Diary is on Twitter at @gdncountrydiary

headline: Fresh support needed if UK lockdowns linger, warn business leaders
standfirst:
Country is on course for a short-term boom this summer, but concern mounts over India Covid variant

  • Coronavirus ‚Äì latest updates
  • See all our coronavirus coverage
trailText: Country is on course for a short-term boom this summer, but concern mounts over India Covid variant
body:
Boris Johnson has been warned by business leaders that a fresh package of economic support would be required if rising Covid-19 infections prevent the further relaxation of pandemic restrictions next month.

After the reopening of hospitality venues indoors across all four nations of the UK, the Guardian‚Äôs latest monthly assessment of economic developments suggests the country is on course for a short-term growth boom this summer.

Retail sales have surged above pre-pandemic levels, while customers returning to restaurants, pubs and cafes have driven a sharp rise in consumer spending to begin repairing the damage from the worst recession in 300 years.

However, concerns are mounting over the Covid variant first detected in India ‚Äì B.1.617.2 ‚Äì and the possibility that rising infections could delay the next phase of the government‚Äôs roadmap for relaxing controls in England.

Kate Nicholls, the chief executive of UK Hospitality, said that despite substantial progress being made, the last month had been ‚Äúfar from a champagne moment for the industry‚Äù after the cumulative damage from repeated closures over the past year.

Writing in the Guardian, she said any delay to government‚Äôs roadmap would require the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, to bring forward a fresh package of financial support and to consider extending the furlough scheme.

‚ÄúAt this point, any delay to the removal of restrictions on 21 June will be nothing short of catastrophic for a sector that has already lost ¬£80bn in sales ‚Äì two-thirds of its pre-pandemic revenue ‚Äì over the past year.

‚ÄúShould there be one, it needs to be communicated well in advance and come with further support,‚Äù she said.

In the past year, the Guardian has tracked the economic fallout from the pandemic on a monthly basis, following infection rates, eight key growth indicators and the level of the FTSE 100. Faced with the deepest global recession since the Great Depression, the Covid crisis watch also monitors Britain‚Äôs performance compared with other countries.

On the dashboard in the past month, the number of people eating out in restaurants has risen to 75% above the levels recorded on comparable days two years ago, before the pandemic struck, amid evidence of pent-up demand from consumers confined to staying at home for much of the year so far.

Public transport usage has climbed to the highest point since the health emergency first spread to Britain last year, with more people heading into town and city centres for leisure and work than at any time since the crisis began.

The reopening of non-essential shops in April helped drive retail sales to more than 10% above pre-pandemic levels, while closely watched business surveys reveal the fastest monthly growth in private sector activity since the late 1990s.

Against a backdrop of improving economic prospects and rapid progress with the Covid-19 vaccination programme, unemployment fell for a third month running in March as companies ramped up their hiring plans in anticipation of reopening.

However, more than 4m jobs remained furloughed, reflecting continued pressure on the economy while social distancing measures remain in place and as global travel restrictions weigh on the travel industry.

Although there is evidence of a rapid economic recovery taking hold, the British economy is expected to take until the end of 2021 to return to its pre-crisis peak. According to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, the economy is on track to suffer more than ¬£700bn of lost output as a result of the crisis, with the fallout made worse by the government‚Äôs mishandling of the health emergency last year and the impact of Brexit.

Prolonged government restrictions beyond June could push back the point at which the economy returns to its pre-pandemic peak, while the prospect of a slower recovery could push up job losses when the government‚Äôs furlough scheme is scaled back from the end of next month.

From July, employers will need to contribute 10% of an employee‚Äôs wage, rising to 20% in August, as taxpayer support is cut from the current level of 80%. Employees will continue to receive the same amount.

Nicholls said a package of economic support would be needed if there are delays on the roadmap, including deferring business rates repayments, extending commercial rent protections and cutting VAT.

‚ÄúThe government would also need to look again at the future of the furlough scheme, as operators will not be in a position to contribute further if they are still trading under restrictions. This would inevitably result in large numbers of jobs being lost,‚Äù she said.

headline: Operator of unvaccinated Melbourne nursing home rejects minister‚Äôs claim residents opted out
standfirst:
Operators challenge claim by aged care minister Richard Colbeck that some of the Victorian facilities still waiting for the vaccine ‚Äòhave chosen not to take the jab‚Äô

  • Record pace of Melbourne outbreak and delayed vaccine rollout blamed for lockdown
  • Follow Thursday‚Äôs liveblog
  • Victoria‚Äôs Covid lockdown restrictions: new rules explained
  • Victoria Covid-19 hotspots and exposure sites
trailText: Operators challenge claim by aged care minister Richard Colbeck that some of the Victorian facilities still waiting for the vaccine ‚Äòhave chosen not to take the jab‚Äô
body:
The families of residents at an unvaccinated Melbourne aged care home say they are ‚Äúflabbergasted‚Äù by comments from aged care minister Richard Colbeck who claimed those not yet vaccinated ‚Äúhave chosen not to take the jab‚Äù.

As the Victorian government announced its fourth lockdown on Thursday, there were 29 aged care facilities in the state that had not yet received their first dose of the Covid vaccine, while 569 facilities had received just one dose. Hours later, the federal health minister, Greg Hunt, revealed the number yet to receive their first doses had shrunk to 16 homes since yesterday‚Äôs figures.

On Thursday morning, Colbeck, when asked by Channel Nine how he‚Äôd feel if he was a resident in a home that hadn‚Äôt received a first dose yet, suggested that some of the facilities had chosen to delay their rollouts.

Related: Just three of 13 promised vaccine hubs for Australia‚Äôs young aged care workers have opened

‚ÄúSome of them have chosen not to take the jab, which is I find a little disappointing, but it‚Äôs been their choice,‚Äù Colbeck said.

Colbeck later said he was ‚Äúvery comfortable‚Äù with vaccination rates in aged care, noting the homes yet to receive a single dose ‚Äúwere programmed to be done this week or next week, so we‚Äôll get those finalised as quickly as we can‚Äù.

However operators of unvaccinated aged care facilities in Melbourne have challenged Colbeck‚Äôs claim that they opted not to receive the vaccine.

First-dose vaccinations were scheduled for Jewish Care‚Äôs aged care facility in Windsor, in Melbourne‚Äôs inner south, on 11 May.

The doses were to be administered by a mobile Health Care Australia team, however the vaccinations were cancelled on the morning they were set to begin, after one of the Health Care Australia team member‚Äôs fell ill. They have since been rescheduled for next month.

In a correspondence to residents and their families, Jewish Care said ‚ÄúHealth Care Australia were unable to replace the team leader and following safety protocols were left with no option but to cancel at the last minute‚Äù.

Abe Schwarz, whose 92-year-old mother is a resident at the Windsor home, was furious at the suggestion she did not want a vaccine.

‚ÄúWhen I heard that the responsible minister suggested that my mum and others were not getting the jab because it was their choice, I was flabbergasted,‚Äù Schwarz.

Schwarz said he had prepared his mother for the vaccine, and said he was ‚Äúaghast‚Äù when he received an email informing him at 8am that the vaccinations scheduled to begin at 9am had been cancelled.

His mother, who has dementia, contracted Covid last year in the home, but recovered.

He is now worried the unvaccinated state of the home will cause further visitation delays beyond the initial terms of the lockdown.

‚ÄúI will be so upset, as would any other caring family, if the government stuff up one hour before the vaccinations, if that continues to be the reason why we can‚Äôt visit our elders.

‚ÄúDementia sufferers rely on family visits. I‚Äôll be heartbroken,‚Äù Schwarz said.

The Windsor home recorded two resident deaths during Melbourne‚Äôs second wave last year, and families of residents have told Guardian Australia they were eager for the facility to be vaccinated.

Bill Appleby, Jewish Care‚Äôs chief executive, told Guardian Australia his organisation ‚Äúwas very disappointed with the last-minute cancellation of the Covid vaccination‚Äù.

‚ÄúClearly any delay is concerning given the vulnerability of the elderly and the fact that we have an outbreak in metropolitan Melbourne. Additionally, any delay has a subsequent impact on influenza vaccination for our elders,‚Äù Appleby said.

Josh Burns, the Labor MP for Macnamara which includes the Windsor home, said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs infuriating that an aged care facility, who endured an outbreak and lost residents to this virus last year, have still not been vaccinated.

Related: Record pace of Melbourne Covid outbreak and delayed vaccine rollout blamed for Victoria lockdown

‚ÄúScott Morrison received his jab three months ago and yet these most vulnerable Australians in my electorate are still completely unprotected with a live outbreak,‚Äù he said.

The opposition health and ageing spokesman, Mark Butler, said the fact that 29 Victorian aged care homes had not yet received a first dose by Wednesday was ‚Äúa scandal‚Äù.

‚ÄúAll of the residents of aged care facilities across Australia were promised full vaccination by Easter by Scott Morrison,‚Äù Butler said.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think residents at the 29 facilities that have received not a single dose said ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt want the vaccine.‚Äô It‚Äôs just the commonwealth has not got their act together.‚Äù

In an interview with ABC, Butler said there was ‚Äúno shortage‚Äù of vaccine supply and that the federal government should put more resources into vaccinating the aged care population ‚Äúas a priority‚Äù.

Earlier in May, medical professionals told Guardian Australia the cold chain delivery and specialist mobile teams required to administer the Pfizer vaccine were at capacity because of the rollout across aged-care homes, and that a sick day by even a single staff member was forcing vaccinations scheduled for some facilities to be abandoned and their residents moved to the bottom of the queue.

Do you know more about unvaccinated aged care homes? Contact elias.visontay@theguardian.com.
bodyText: The families of residents at an unvaccinated Melbourne aged care home say they are ‚Äúflabbergasted‚Äù by comments from aged care minister Richard Colbeck who claimed those not yet vaccinated ‚Äúhave chosen not to take the jab‚Äù. As the Victorian government announced its fourth lockdown on Thursday, there were 29 aged care facilities in the state that had not yet received their first dose of the Covid vaccine, while 569 facilities had received just one dose. Hours later, the federal health minister, Greg Hunt, revealed the number yet to receive their first doses had shrunk to 16 homes since yesterday‚Äôs figures. On Thursday morning, Colbeck, when asked by Channel Nine how he‚Äôd feel if he was a resident in a home that hadn‚Äôt received a first dose yet, suggested that some of the facilities had chosen to delay their rollouts. ‚ÄúSome of them have chosen not to take the jab, which is I find a little disappointing, but it‚Äôs been their choice,‚Äù Colbeck said. Colbeck later said he was ‚Äúvery comfortable‚Äù with vaccination rates in aged care, noting the homes yet to receive a single dose ‚Äúwere programmed to be done this week or next week, so we‚Äôll get those finalised as quickly as we can‚Äù. However operators of unvaccinated aged care facilities in Melbourne have challenged Colbeck‚Äôs claim that they opted not to receive the vaccine. First-dose vaccinations were scheduled for Jewish Care‚Äôs aged care facility in Windsor, in Melbourne‚Äôs inner south, on 11 May. The doses were to be administered by a mobile Health Care Australia team, however the vaccinations were cancelled on the morning they were set to begin, after one of the Health Care Australia team member‚Äôs fell ill. They have since been rescheduled for next month. In a correspondence to residents and their families, Jewish Care said ‚ÄúHealth Care Australia were unable to replace the team leader and following safety protocols were left with no option but to cancel at the last minute‚Äù. Abe Schwarz, whose 92-year-old mother is a resident at the Windsor home, was furious at the suggestion she did not want a vaccine. ‚ÄúWhen I heard that the responsible minister suggested that my mum and others were not getting the jab because it was their choice, I was flabbergasted,‚Äù Schwarz. Schwarz said he had prepared his mother for the vaccine, and said he was ‚Äúaghast‚Äù when he received an email informing him at 8am that the vaccinations scheduled to begin at 9am had been cancelled. His mother, who has dementia, contracted Covid last year in the home, but recovered. He is now worried the unvaccinated state of the home will cause further visitation delays beyond the initial terms of the lockdown. ‚ÄúI will be so upset, as would any other caring family, if the government stuff up one hour before the vaccinations, if that continues to be the reason why we can‚Äôt visit our elders. ‚ÄúDementia sufferers rely on family visits. I‚Äôll be heartbroken,‚Äù Schwarz said. The Windsor home recorded two resident deaths during Melbourne‚Äôs second wave last year, and families of residents have told Guardian Australia they were eager for the facility to be vaccinated. Bill Appleby, Jewish Care‚Äôs chief executive, told Guardian Australia his organisation ‚Äúwas very disappointed with the last-minute cancellation of the Covid vaccination‚Äù. ‚ÄúClearly any delay is concerning given the vulnerability of the elderly and the fact that we have an outbreak in metropolitan Melbourne. Additionally, any delay has a subsequent impact on influenza vaccination for our elders,‚Äù Appleby said. Josh Burns, the Labor MP for Macnamara which includes the Windsor home, said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs infuriating that an aged care facility, who endured an outbreak and lost residents to this virus last year, have still not been vaccinated. ‚ÄúScott Morrison received his jab three months ago and yet these most vulnerable Australians in my electorate are still completely unprotected with a live outbreak,‚Äù he said. The opposition health and ageing spokesman, Mark Butler, said the fact that 29 Victorian aged care homes had not yet received a first dose by Wednesday was ‚Äúa scandal‚Äù. ‚ÄúAll of the residents of aged care facilities across Australia were promised full vaccination by Easter by Scott Morrison,‚Äù Butler said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think residents at the 29 facilities that have received not a single dose said ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt want the vaccine.‚Äô It‚Äôs just the commonwealth has not got their act together.‚Äù In an interview with ABC, Butler said there was ‚Äúno shortage‚Äù of vaccine supply and that the federal government should put more resources into vaccinating the aged care population ‚Äúas a priority‚Äù. Earlier in May, medical professionals told Guardian Australia the cold chain delivery and specialist mobile teams required to administer the Pfizer vaccine were at capacity because of the rollout across aged-care homes, and that a sick day by even a single staff member was forcing vaccinations scheduled for some facilities to be abandoned and their residents moved to the bottom of the queue. Do you know more about unvaccinated aged care homes? Contact elias.visontay@theguardian.com.

headline: Record pace of Melbourne Covid outbreak and delayed vaccine rollout blamed for Victoria lockdown
standfirst:
Officials say a seven-day lockdown is needed because the coronavirus variant is spreading faster than contact tracers can keep up with

  • Victoria‚Äôs Covid lockdown restrictions: new rules explained
  • Victoria Covid-19 hotspots and exposure sites
  • Follow LIVE Covid updates: Victoria goes into seven-day lockdown
trailText: Officials say a seven-day lockdown is needed because the coronavirus variant is spreading faster than contact tracers can keep up with
body:
Victorian contact tracers are in danger of being overwhelmed by a Covid-19 outbreak ‚Äúrunning faster than we have ever recorded‚Äù, the acting Victorian premier James Merlino said as he announced a seven-day circuit-breaker lockdown.

Merlino said on Thursday contact tracers were struggling to keep up despite quickly identifying more than 10,000 primary and secondary contacts and 150 potential exposure sites, as the number of positive cases linked to the cluster reached 26.

‚ÄúThe usual transmission is about five to six days. In some of these cases, within a day it‚Äôs being transmitted,‚Äù Merlino said. ‚ÄúThe number of cases has doubled in 24 hours. Unless something drastic happens, this will become increasingly uncontrollable.‚Äù

Related: AFL scrambles again as Melbourne lockdown causes chaos for sport

The B1617.1 variant, first identified in India, is responsible for Victoria‚Äôs cluster. While it is not the most infectious variant in India, it is nonetheless concerning, and at least as infectious as the B.1.1.7 variant prevalent in Britain.

‚ÄúFrom first thing this morning, we have identified in excess of 10,000 primary and secondary contacts who will need to either quarantine, or test and isolate, and that number will continue to grow and change,‚Äù Merlino said.

‚ÄúOur public health experts‚Äô primary concern is how fast this variant is moving. We‚Äôve seen overseas how difficult that movement can be to control. Here in Victoria, we‚Äôre seeing not only how quick it is, but how contagious it is as well.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the fastest our contact tracers have ever moved within a 24-hour period, identifying and locking down first, second and third rings of cases. But despite working as fast as this, and my thanks to all of our contact tracers, this variant is moving faster still.‚Äù

One elderly person with the virus is now in intensive care and on a ventilator, the acting premier said.

As of 11:59pm Thursday, the five reasons for Victorians to leave home include shopping for necessary goods and services; authorised work or permitted education; exercise; care giving; and medical reasons, including to get vaccinated. The lockdown will last for seven days.

Half of Victorians are now eligible to be vaccinated, as Merlino also announced those aged 40 and above can now book in for the Pfizer vaccine.

‚ÄúThe vaccine rollout has been slower than we have hoped,‚Äù Merlino said.

He added a lack of suitable quarantine facilities and a reluctance from some people to get vaccinated had been frustrating. Since the current outbreak in Victoria, however, record numbers of people have been vaccinated.

On Thursday morning, the vaccine booking website had crashed and the hotline was busy.

Asked if Victorians should feel angry at the federal government given the slow pace of the rollout and lack of suitable purpose-built quarantine, Merlino responded: ‚ÄúIt is a fact that the commonwealth vaccine rollout has been delayed and there are global reasons for that delay.

‚ÄúWe have also seen a reluctance from some people to get vaccinated when they are eligible,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is a fact that we have aged care facilities where not one person has been vaccinated. These are facts. We need to get this vaccination rolled out as quickly as possible, and that is why we have been doing a lot of work about how we can quickly expand what we offer at our state sites.‚Äù

Health authorities were also questioned about the state contact-tracing system and whether it had been too slow. The chief health officer, Professor Brett Sutton, said the suggestion was ‚Äúabsurd‚Äù and contact tracers had worked quickly.

Related: Victoria Covid public exposure sites: full list of Melbourne venues and Vic coronavirus hotspots and case location alerts

‚ÄúIt is an absurd proposition that contact tracing has gone wrong,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe have talked about exactly what the contact-tracing team have done here, and it is extraordinary. Contact tracing is an integral part of how to get control. It does not do magic.‚Äù

Asked why the state was not locked down sooner, Sutton said: ‚ÄúWe have to act on the information before us at any time.‚Äù

Off the back of the news, the Western Australia premier announced a hard border closure with Victoria as of 10am. ‚ÄúThis means that travel from Victoria or travel to Western Australia from anyone who has been in Victoria from May 16 will no longer be permitted unless you are an exempt traveller,‚Äù he said.

headline: I got out of Australia to be with my dying mother. But thousands remain in limbo
standfirst: I completed hotel quarantine with two toddlers while grieving. It was fine. It‚Äôs the lack of a plan that wears a soul down
trailText: I completed hotel quarantine with two toddlers while grieving. It was fine. It‚Äôs the lack of a plan that wears a soul down
body:
It is exactly six months and one week since my mother died on a rainy November evening in England. The country had just been thrown into another lockdown, this time with schools open and pubs shut. The sun shone once that day, a curtain of silver that poured from a split in the deep grey and dissolved as quickly as it appeared.

Related: With Australia‚Äôs delayed vaccine rollout, a reunion with my parents overseas inches further from reach | Jill Stark

Five days earlier, in a haze of panic and sick with fear, I had somehow mustered enough clarity to fill in an exemption to leave application and satisfy the Australian government‚Äôs unique and harsh border restrictions. I had scrambled for letters from doctors, submitted images of my dying mother, bought flights I knew wouldn‚Äôt fly, flung winter clothes together for myself and my two toddlers and kissed my husband goodbye, not knowing when we‚Äôd get back to him. I doused my children in sanitiser as we made our way through darkened, hushed airports, bus terminals and train stations in three countries. By the time I reached my mother in her care home, I knew only to strip away my regulation top-to-toe PPE and climb into her bed, resting my head on her shoulder and stroking her soft, cool hand.

Last winter, I wrote about my fears of being unable to get to my sick mother in the UK and how, for better or worse, my life in Australia depended on the air traffic that blights the skies but delivers so many of us to our loved ones. It turned out that the very worst did eventuate ‚Äì but, in a perversity of norms that could only be wrought by a deeply human crisis, my experience was also a small miracle, given this moment, in this place, in this pandemic.

I‚Äôm Australian and I got to her in time. For every story like mine, there are thousands that end with a computer says no thud.

I have heard of babies who haven‚Äôt met their fathers and wives who haven‚Äôt seen their husbands in 18 months. There‚Äôs a friend whose father passed away from Covid and couldn‚Äôt get to him in time. And another, whose father hid the extent of his stage four cancer from her so that she wouldn‚Äôt have to confront the risk of no exemption and dumbfounding costs of flights. Then there‚Äôs my British father, who wants nothing more than to scatter his Australian wife of nearly 50 years‚Äô ashes, sort out her affairs and spend time with his Australian daughters and grandchildren. Yet, parents don‚Äôt count as close family and so, the answer, once again, is a no.

Like so many here without family overseas and those looking on from abroad, he doesn‚Äôt get it. They can‚Äôt get their heads around our border closure. Is that even allowed? They ask.

I completed hotel quarantine with a two and a three-year-old while grieving. It wasn‚Äôt hard compared to the uncertainty that came before it on Australian soil ‚Äì not being able to freely visit my unwell mother, the fears over how I‚Äôd secure an exemption and afford flights, the predicted (and extremely pricey) battles to get seats home to Sydney. No, quarantine was fine. Quarantine makes sense. It‚Äôs the lack of a plan that really wears a soul down.

Related: Third Australian dies of Covid in India while caring for elderly parents

November feels like a bad dream, but the perversity continues, because, now, after my mother‚Äôs death has come a subtle sense of grim relief. The limbo of watching from afar, helpless and desperate, is over. I will never have to submit another exemption to travel request to the heavy machinery of the federal government moments after seeing her, supine and hollow-cheeked, as a nurse held an iPad over her deathbed. And with that knowing, that immensely sad knowing, the stories of the missed deaths and illness and human moments strike me with the force of a body blow. I got out and came back when so many couldn‚Äôt and won‚Äôt ‚Äì and their limbo stretches on. My attention has turned to my father and my in-laws, whose family is us, here, too far away. For now, we must wait for the too slow vaccine rollout and for confidence to nudge away fear.

The virus can reach us, no matter how long we are kept apart from family and loved ones, no matter how long we are prevented from finishing university courses and starting jobs and maintaining businesses and giving safe harbour to refugees. Keep us locked in and the world locked out until doomsday and the virus still finds us.

When I was a little girl, my school motto was ut sibi sic alteri. Treat others how you‚Äôd like to be treated. Nowadays, I‚Äôd add: even, and especially, when fearful. It‚Äôs what makes us human.

headline: ‚ÄòDomshell‚Äô: what the papers say about Dominic Cummings‚Äô attack on Boris Johnson
standfirst: The extraordinary performance by the former senior aide ‚Äì and his unprecedented accusations against the PM ‚Äì dominate the front pages
trailText: The extraordinary performance by the former senior aide ‚Äì and his unprecedented accusations against the PM ‚Äì dominate the front pages
body:
It was an extraordinary day in British politics. A rain of fire. A grenade. A ‚ÄúDomshell‚Äù.

Dominic Cummings‚Äô seven-hour performance before Westminster MPs on Wednesday filled the UK front pages on Thursday, with his condemnation of Boris Johnson‚Äôs handling of the pandemic dominating headlines.

The Guardian leads with Cummings‚Äô devastating accusation that ‚Äútens of thousands of people died who didn‚Äôt need to die‚Äù during the Covid outbreak in Britain, above a triptych of faces the ousted aide made during the hearing. The Guardian also carried analysis by political editor Heather Stewart calling the hearing self-serving but plausible.

The Independent, the i and the Mirror use the same quote for their splashes. The Independent described the hearing as ‚Äúpainting a picture of disarray in No. 10, as the PM said he wanted to be like the ‚Äòmayor of Jaws‚Äô who kept the beach open despite shark attacks‚Äù:

‚ÄúChaos and complacency‚Äù, writes the i, calling the evidence ‚Äúdevastating‚Äù. The front page quotes a senior official as saying, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre f***ked‚Äù ‚Äì a reference to what Cummings alleges deputy cabinet secretary Helen MacNamara said in March 2020.

The Mirror‚Äôs headline appears over a photo of the PM with his head hanging, titled ‚ÄúJohnson‚Äôs shame‚Äù and captioned ‚ÄúPM in crisis after explosive claims‚Äù.

The Telegraph takes a different tack, labelling the accusations from Cummings as ‚Äúrevenge‚Äù. Johnson booted his top adviser in November last year following allegations that he had briefed against the PM.

‚ÄúSources last night raised questions over his motives,‚Äù the Telegraph writes, ‚Äúsuggesting the public would see him as bitter‚Äù. The paper throws forward to Thursday, when the government will ‚Äúattempt to fight back‚Äù as the health secretary, Matt Hancock, answers questions in the House of Commons before holding a press conference.

The Sunday Telegraph editor, Alistair Heath, argues that ‚ÄúSlowly but surely, the side-effects of the lockdown and of the pandemic itself will become more salient, and the death toll itself less so‚Äù, in a comment piece titled ‚ÄúCovid could yet destroy Johnson. But not in the way Cummings expects‚Äù.

The Daily Express calls Cummings‚Äô performance a ‚Äútirade‚Äù, with the headline: ‚ÄúYes, mistakes were made but this was pure revenge‚Äù. The paper quotes ‚Äúallies‚Äù of the PM calling Cummings ‚Äúvengeful and embittered‚Äù.

The Times says ‚ÄúCummings rains fire on No 10‚Äù. It, too, quotes an unnamed government source‚Äôs claim that Cummings ‚Äúwas motivated by revenge and that his comments represented a ‚Äòcharacter assassination‚Äô that was not backed by evidence‚Äù.

The front page comment calls the hearing ‚Äúprimal chaos, as molten and Sicilian as anything disgorged by Mount Etna‚Äù and ‚Äúlonger and bloodier than Hamlet‚Äù.

‚ÄúOnly in England could a major health ding-dong include a cameo for a Jack Russell‚Äù ‚Äì a reference to Cummings saying that the PM and his girlfriend, Carrie Symonds, distracted the PM from the pandemic because she was ‚Äúgoing completely crackers‚Äù about press coverage of their dog.

The FT and the Yorkshire Post take their headlines from Cummings‚Äô one-word response ‚Äì ‚ÄúNo‚Äù ‚Äì when asked whether the prime minister was a fit and proper person to lead the country through the pandemic:

The Daily Record‚Äôs headline is ‚ÄúBlood on your hands‚Äù, beside a photo of the prime minister. The paper‚Äôs story on the hearing takes up no fewer than pages ‚Äú4,5,6,7,8&9‚Äù.

The Daily Mail ‚Äì and sister paper Metro ‚Äì are peerless in the pun department, with ‚ÄúDomshell‚Äù. Its front page also brands the PM ‚Äúshopping trolley Boris‚Äù, after Cummings portrayed Johnson as making constant U-turns ‚Äúlike a shopping trolley smashing from one side of the aisle to the other‚Äù.

The Scotsman sums up the spectacle as ‚ÄúThe Cummings Grenade‚Äù, including in its main dot points Cummings‚Äô assertion that SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon undermined the four-nations response to the pandemic. Cummings said in the hearings, ‚ÄúAs soon as you had these meetings Nicola Sturgeon would just go straight out announce what she wanted straight afterwards,‚Äù and called the meetings ‚ÄúPotemkin‚Äù.

In other coverage, former justice secretary David Gauke said in an appearance on BBC Newsnight: ‚ÄúIt strikes me that with Dominic Cummings you‚Äôre either brilliant or you‚Äôre useless and clearly he‚Äôs consigned Matt Hancock to the second category. That‚Äôs not my experience.‚Äù

Asked by Emily Maitlis whether Cummings‚Äô apology for lives lost meant Johnson should apologise, too, Gauke said: ‚ÄúWell I think it probably does and I think it‚Äôs very difficult for the government to argue that these are matters that should only be looked at in due course after an enquiry.‚Äù
